job_title: Deputy Title IX Coordinator in Scranton, PA

cons: Pay is mediocre for the field, and they will try to keep yours artificially low if you get a promotion. Lots of restructuring to keep one person, which is untenable after that person leaves.

pros: Excellent education for students; Proud alumni; Tight-knit community; Beautiful campus; New President, Fr. Marina, shows promising vision for future organizational change; Stays true to the Catholic/Jesuit mission; Excellent medical and tuition remission benefits, and positive reputation in Northeast PA.
cons:
Not very diverse in terms of race and female representation at the top.
Stagnant policies, hard to innovate/inspire change.
Processes move slowly, particularly related to IT and system improvement. Managers aren't held accountable for performance issues; very rare that someone is terminated, even when they are under-performing.
Frustrating work environment for fast-paced, innovative, hard workers, and raises/financial incentives are very rare and modest.
Not the place for ambitious people who ask tough questions and challenge the norm.
Not good at trusting/accommodating work-from-home/innovative work schedules even though it is offered as an option through HR.

pros: The campus is lovely, the people are kind-- as long as you stay within your own social class, you will have a good experience. The benefits are some of the best in this area. If you have a supervisor you work well with you will enjoy encouragement, flexibility and support.
cons: The culture of the University is out of date. If you are not from Scranton, and don't have a connection of some sort to the area you will have a difficult time feeling accepted in Scranton. If you are not part of the 'in-crowd' you will not be recognized for your contributions. Clerical and maintenance staff, in particular, have little in the way of career advancement opportunities.

review_title: Quite decent, with some recent hickups
pros: The work environment may vary from one department to another, but overall it's a decent place to work. The U has been growing rapidly with a few new centers and buildings being opened within the last few years. Salaries are quite competitive and the health coverage has been the best in the area.
cons: Again, it's a big institution and the cons may vary across different departments. Recently there has been a lot of tension between faculty and administration. The faculty union had to call a semi-strike that lasted for about a month. As of this writing the tension hasn't subsided yet.

pros:
For the most part the institution really embraces its Jesuit identity, with all its implications.  There is a fairly strong sense of cohesion among faculty in at least two of the colleges, a real care for the wellbeing of students, a genuine engagement with issues of social justice, considered in a historically broad sense. 
Salaries are very good for a place that is cheap to live.  Benefits are excellent.
cons:
We are not immune to the proliferation of administrators that that is absolutely endemic in the academy: much  wasteful bureacratic flappery and some degree of self-serving pusillanimity. 
The Admissions department is a little fiefdom, with seemingly little sense of responsibility to the identity of the institutition.

review_title: It was friendly environment and good work.
pros: One of the best reasons to work here is because you are surrounded by people, professors and students, who are smart and enjoy doing their job. It is a place for people who want not a job but a career.
cons: They're aren't many cons. The work area is great but maybe one con is the location of scranton not being preferable due to harsh winters and other things.

pros: Working in the Study Abroad Office allows you to share your international experiences with students that want to have their own. The staff is a great group of people, with amazing stories of their travels. Michael is a wonderful guy, a great boss, and creates a comfortable atmosphere for work.
cons: The only con working here was continually explaining how easy it is to study abroad, and professors telling students that they couldn't even though we have ways of sending students from every major to experience life abroad.

pros: Many departments work together, engaging in university community development. Our Jesuit Mission is important to all areas of our institution. We have just moderate turn-over, as many of our employees want to work here with out venturing out to places unknown. Beautiful campus, our grounds and maintenance groups are the best.
cons: We live in NEPA... where the weather is not at all predictable. Parking is a challenge, making errand runs almost impossible during lunch. Honestly, it's difficult to pull together much to complain about here.

pros: Plenty of room to move up and excellent benefits. A usually friendly environment and a good amount of support for their employees.
cons: There are the occasional standard private university issues and challenges. There's also a low turn around rate (which is good!) but can lead to some complacency.
